pull.title: doc: added note about brew and Qt 6 on macOS
pull.body:
In the issues: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/25947 and https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/21901 , I and others did not follow the instructions despite intending to do so.

So I created this simple documentation update for`doc/build-osx.md` in a way that I expect it would have caught my attention.

events.body:
@Sjors 

Thank you for your review, I have partly adopted @jarolrod suggestions:
- Include a brief reason why the compiling will fail.
- Remove the link to the issue as suggested.
- I chose not make the assumption that the user already has `qt` installed; maybe they install it after and find their builds stop working!

crACK 0d600b999934a55c765cb2dcfd3ca64370dbcc97

Note: documentation/comments related commits are prefixed with `doc:` (in lowercase), not `Docs:`. So the commit message should be updated to `doc: added note about brew and Qt 6 on macOS` or something similar.

rename.from: Docs: macOS, make note about brew and Qt 6 more explicit.
rename.to: doc: added note about brew and Qt 6 on macOS

events.body: @Zero-1729 Thank you, I have updated the message of the comment according to your suggestion.

verification.payload:
tree f67ba2077e0f1c7dc66ba44f8f18d253e2ad7299
parent 2557429d2b82fe5ba308b940bcf14c3047634345
author Cameron Garnham <me@da2ce7.com> 1662179609 +0200
committer Cameron Garnham <me@da2ce7.com> 1662636462 +0200

doc: added note about brew and Qt 6 on macOS

events.message: doc: added note about brew and Qt 6 on macOS

events.body: Seems like we should just fix the bug. Unrelated packages shouldn't cause problems.

ACK 7d67976d6d4e454f958d923189095a0484383712,

I also dealt with this problem once. This version of the docs would probably save me a round-trip to my favourite search-engine.

~0

[Having both qt5 and qt6 installed, on an M1 macOS system doesn't cause any issues](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/25947#issuecomment-1241793324), so I don't think the problem has been properly/fully identified, and this addition would be incorrect for modern / macOS systems going forward.

> Seems like we should just fix the bug. Unrelated packages shouldn't cause problems.

> [Having both qt5 and qt6 installed, on an M1 macOS system doesn't cause any issues](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/25947#issuecomment-1241793324), so I don't think the problem has been properly/fully identified, and this addition would be incorrect for modern / macOS systems going forward.

Also https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/25947#issuecomment-1242343491

Agree with @luke-jr and @fanquake -- let's fully identify the problem first.
Reading through the comments and issue, agree as well, makes sense to narrow down the issue.

> Reading through the comments and issue, agree as well, makes sense to narrow down the issue.

#26056 could fix it.
Going to close this in favour of fixing the code. Would be great if anyone who's run into this issue could test #26056 instead.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -96,11 +96,13 @@ Skip if you don't intend to use the GUI.
 brew install qt@5
 ```
 
-Ensure that the `qt@5` package is installed, not the `qt` package.
-If 'qt' is installed, the build process will fail.
-if installed, remove the `qt` package with the following command:
+_Note:_ Ensure that _only_ `qt@5` is installed:
+> If the `qt` package, i.e. 'Qt 6', is installed, configuring Bitcoin will find 'Qt 5' as expected, however the build process will still fail. [#25947](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/25947)
comments.body:
I wouldn't move this into quotes, no need for that. I also wouldn't link to a specific issue here, and some cleanup suggestions.

```suggestion
If you've previously grabbed the `qt` package, which installs Qt 6, you will not be able to compile.
```

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -96,11 +96,13 @@ Skip if you don't intend to use the GUI.
 brew install qt@5
 ```
 
-Ensure that the `qt@5` package is installed, not the `qt` package.
-If 'qt' is installed, the build process will fail.
-if installed, remove the `qt` package with the following command:
+_Note:_ Ensure that _only_ `qt@5` is installed:
+> If the `qt` package, i.e. 'Qt 6', is installed, configuring Bitcoin will find 'Qt 5' as expected, however the build process will still fail. [#25947](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/25947)
+
+You may check for and uninstall packages with the following commands:
comments.body:
```suggestion
You may check for and uninstall the `qt` package with the following commands:
```

comments.body:
**nit**: This seems to be the only place where "Note" is italicized in the doc; it might be worth reverting to match the other notes. Italicizing also seems redundant here for emphasis, as it's already a note. 

```suggestion
Note: Ensure that _only_ `qt@5` is installed:
```

@@ -96,11 +96,13 @@ Skip if you don't intend to use the GUI.

 ```
 
-Ensure that the `qt@5` package is installed, not the `qt` package.
-If 'qt' is installed, the build process will fail.
-if installed, remove the `qt` package with the following command:
+_Note:_ Ensure that _only_ `qt@5` is installed:

@@ -96,11 +96,13 @@ Skip if you don't intend to use the GUI.
 brew install qt@5
 ```
 
-Ensure that the `qt@5` package is installed, not the `qt` package.
-If 'qt' is installed, the build process will fail.
-if installed, remove the `qt` package with the following command:
+Note: Ensure that _only_ `qt@5` is installed:
+> If the `qt` package, which provides Qt 6, is installed alongside `qt@5`, configuring will find Qt 5, but compiling will fail because some headers are incorrectly imported from Qt 6 locations.
comments.body:
Please unquote this
```suggestion
If the `qt` package, which provides Qt 6, is installed alongside `qt@5`, configuring will find Qt 5, but compiling will fail because some headers are incorrectly imported from Qt 6 locations.
```

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -96,11 +96,13 @@ Skip if you don't intend to use the GUI.
 brew install qt@5
 ```
 
-Ensure that the `qt@5` package is installed, not the `qt` package.
-If 'qt' is installed, the build process will fail.
-if installed, remove the `qt` package with the following command:
+Note: Ensure that _only_ `qt@5` is installed:
+> If the `qt` package, which provides Qt 6, is installed alongside `qt@5`, configuring will find Qt 5, but compiling will fail because some headers are incorrectly imported from Qt 6 locations.
comments.body:
It's sufficient to say that you can't build if qt6 is installed, we don't need to go into any technical detail. The only information needed is that `qt@5` is the proper package and not `qt6`. I'd still prefer something like this:
```suggestion
If you've previously grabbed the `qt` package, which installs Qt 6, you will not be able to compile.
```

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -96,11 +96,13 @@ Skip if you don't intend to use the GUI.
 brew install qt@5
 ```
 
-Ensure that the `qt@5` package is installed, not the `qt` package.
-If 'qt' is installed, the build process will fail.
-if installed, remove the `qt` package with the following command:
+Note: Ensure that _only_ `qt@5` is installed:
+> If the `qt` package, which provides Qt 6, is installed alongside `qt@5`, configuring will find Qt 5, but compiling will fail because some headers are incorrectly imported from Qt 6 locations.
comments.body:
@jarolrod I have removed the quote formatting as suggested.

Can you please explain why there is no need to go into rationale that you cannot have both Qt 5 and Qt 6 installed simultaneously?  After-all Qt 6 is becoming quite common now, and it quite reasonable that some developers will think: "Hey, why not? I need Qt 6 for this other project I'm working on.".
